name: Emu
distribution: Endemic to Australia; widespread across the mainland
habitat: Open plains, woodlands, and semi-arid regions
diet: Omnivorous: consumes a variety of plants and insects
behavior: Diurnal; forages during the day and rests at night; capable of running at high speeds
reproduction: Forms breeding pairs during summer; males incubate eggs and care for chicks
uses: Historically used by Indigenous Australians for meat, oil, and feathers
description: The emu is the second-largest living bird by height after the ostrich. Flightless and native to Australia, it is known for its long legs, fast running, and strong survival skills in various environments.

name: Andean_Tinamou
distribution: Andes from southern Ecuador to central Chile; also in the Sierras de Córdoba, Argentina
habitat: Subtropical and tropical shrubland at elevations of 800 to 4,000 meters
diet: Omnivorous: consumes seeds, insects, and plant material
behavior: Ground-dwelling; shy and elusive; capable of short flights but prefers to run when threatened
reproduction: Males incubate eggs and care for chicks; nests are concealed on the ground
uses: Hunted locally for food; not widely used in traditional practices
description: The Andean tinamou is a ground-dwelling bird native to the Andes, characterized by its cryptic plumage and elusive behavior. It inhabits high-altitude shrublands and is known for its distinctive whistling calls.

name: Chestnut-bellied_Guan
distribution: Endemic to Brazil; primarily in the Pantanal and Cerrado regions
habitat: Subtropical or tropical dry forests and swamplands
diet: Omnivorous: feeds on leaves, fruits, seeds, and invertebrates
behavior: Ground-dwelling; shy and elusive; capable of short flights but prefers to run
reproduction: Monogamous; nests are concealed on the ground; typically 2 eggs
uses: Hunted locally for food; threatened by habitat loss due to deforestation
description: Medium-sized bird endemic to Brazil, with chestnut belly and white-spotted plumage.

name: Little_Tinamou
distribution: Central and South America, from southern Mexico to northern South America
diet: Omnivorous: eats seeds, fruits, and small invertebrates
behavior: Secretive and elusive; prefers dense undergrowth; mostly terrestrial
reproduction: Ground-nester; males incubate eggs and care for chicks
uses: Occasionally hunted locally; not widely exploited
description: A small, shy bird that inhabits dense forests, known for its soft whistles and elusive nature.

name: Maleo
habitat: Lowland forests and coastal plains with sandy soils
diet: Primarily fruits, seeds, and small invertebrates
behavior: Terrestrial and shy; active in the morning and late afternoon
reproduction: Lays eggs in geothermal-heated sand; no parental care post-laying
uses: Eggs harvested locally; species threatened by human disturbance
description: The maleo is a striking megapode known for its unique egg-laying in hot sand and endangered status.

name: Malleefowl
habitat: Dry lowland scrub and mallee vegetation
behavior: Builds large nesting mounds; shy and ground-dwelling
reproduction: Male regulates nest temperature; eggs incubated in decomposing mound
uses: Conservation icon in Australia; habitat loss is a threat
description: A ground-nesting bird known for its mound incubation system and limited range in southern Australia.

name: Micronesian_Megapode
reproduction: Eggs incubated in warm sand or compost heaps
uses: Culturally significant; threatened by habitat loss and predation
description: A rare megapode from Micronesia, known for its communal nesting and endangered status.

name: Moluccan_Megapode
distribution: Endemic to the northern Moluccas, Indonesia
behavior: Nocturnal; travels long distances to nesting beaches
reproduction: Lays eggs in warm sandy beaches; no parental care
uses: Eggs harvested by locals; habitat degradation is a threat
description: A unique bird of Indonesia known for its long nocturnal migrations to communal nesting sites.

name: Somali_Ostrich
distribution: Horn of Africa – Somalia, Ethiopia, and northern Kenya
behavior: Flightless; fast runner; forms small groups
reproduction: Polygamous; communal nesting with dominant female laying most eggs
uses: Hunted for feathers, meat, and eggs
description: A large, flightless bird native to East Africa, distinguished by its blue skin and desert adaptation.

name: Speckled_Chachalaca
habitat: Tropical lowland forest and forest edges
behavior: Social and vocal; lives in small groups
reproduction: Builds nests in trees; 2–3 eggs; both parents care for young
uses: Hunted for meat in some areas
description: A noisy forest bird recognized for its spotted plumage and gregarious behavior in South American forests.

name: Spixs_Guan
distribution: Western Amazon Basin (Peru, Brazil, Bolivia, Colombia)
behavior: Arboreal; moves in small family groups
reproduction: Nests in trees; lays 2–3 eggs; female incubates
description: A large forest guan common in the Amazon, known for its fruit-based diet and tree-dwelling habits.
